questions.question: Which type of memory is described as “the workaholic of memory” that runs out and makes things go bad quickly?
When you pass a variable to a functionby copy, what happens if the function modifies the parameter?
options: The original variable is not modified
correct_answers: The original variable is not modified

questions.question: Which option shows the memory hierarchy fromfastest and smallesttoslowest and largest?
What happens when the system runs out of RAM during execution?
options: Nothing, the program just keeps running normally
The system start swapping to slower memory
The CPU automatically makes more registers
The cache takes over and becomes RAM
correct_answers: The system start swapping to slower memory

questions.question: Why don’t we just build a computer with only registers and no other memory?
options: Registers are too slow for I/O
Registers are extremely expensive and limited in count
The compiler does not support registers
correct_answers: Registers are extremely expensive and limited in count

questions.question: Which layer of memory is typicallymanaged automaticallyjust by writing normal C code (no malloc/free)?
Which C function reserves (allocates) memory from the heap?
Which statement is true about heap memory?
options: It is automatically freed when a variable goes out of { } scope
It is manually managed — you must free what you allocate
correct_answers: It is manually managed — you must free what you allocate

questions.question: Which variable lives on the heap?
What happens if you malloc() memory and never free() it?
options: The compiler will free it for you at the end of the loop

questions.question: Passing a parameter by reference is generally preferred over passing by copy when…
options: You want to protect the original data
You want to allow the function to modify the original variable
You are working with very small integers only
You don’t know the function prototype
correct_answers: You want to allow the function to modify the original variable

questions.question: According to the slides, a variable has two “values.” What are they?
options: Its size in bytes and its scope
Its address in flash and its address in RAM
Its current value and its current address
correct_answers: Its current value and its current address

questions.question: Which of the following istrueabout stack memory?
options: It is managed automatically in a last-in-first-out manner
It dynamically resizes at runtime with malloc()
It is slow because it lives in external storage
correct_answers: It is managed automatically in a last-in-first-out manner

questions.question: Which of the following is a limitation of heap memory ?
options: You cannot store large data on the heap
It can fragment and depends on correct manual handling (malloc/free)
You cannot store large data on the heap
correct_answers: It can fragment and depends on correct manual handling (malloc/free)

questions.question: int *p = malloc(100 * sizeof(int)); How manybytesof memory are being requested from the heap?
What is a function pointer?
options: A comment that documents a function
A constant that stores the stack size of a function
A variable that stores the address of a function
correct_answers: A variable that stores the address of a function

questions.question: What is the main reason to use the heap instead of the stack?
options: The heap is always faster than the stack
You need data that persists after the function returns
You don’t want to include stdio.h
The compiler refuses to create local variables
correct_answers: You need data that persists after the function returns
